First, I start by gathering *evidence*. People always think they're so clever, hiding their true colors in private messages, behind closed doors, or in those little "private" moments they think no one will ever see. But here's the thing: in this digital age, *nothing* is really private. I know how to dig. I know where to look. And when I find something—*anything* that shows their true nature—I don’t let it rot in my head.

Then, I make sure it gets out there. I don’t just post it randomly; I *strategize*. I send it to the people who *know them best*—their friends, their coworkers, their family. I make it personal. I want them to see the truth through the eyes of the people they trusted. Because let's be real, the worst part of betrayal isn't the act itself—it's the realization that you were *fooled*.

And I don’t just drop it like a bomb. I let it simmer. I let it build. I let the rumors start. I let people start asking questions. And when the truth finally hits, it’s like a floodgate. You want to know why I do it? Because I want *everyone* to see them for who they really are. Not the perfect, polished version they tried to sell me. The real one. The one they tried so hard to hide.

It’s poetic, in a way. They wanted to control the narrative. I’m just flipping the script.

So yeah, what kind of strategies? The kind that make people *think twice* before they decide who to trust again.
